author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Trove of Ancient Axes Shows Early Humans Made Tools From Bones
description: Deep in a trench in Tanzania, researchers found dozens of tools crafted from animal bones some 1.5 million years old.
content: Humans, unlike most other species, have a knack for making tools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Turkey Meatloaf With a Little Somethin’-Somethin’
description: Can turkey meatloaf be fancy? Because this one, with its stripe of red-wine-spiked tomato sauce, certainly feels a little luxe.
content: Maybe it’s my stint as an interim restaurant critic, but lately I can’t stop thinking about meatloaf. It’s not the sort of thing you find on a menu all that often. As a kid, I ate it on the regular at my grandmother’s house — a thick, ketchup-slicked slice, surrounded by a starch and a green, a good square meal in that classic, midcentury way. And now I’ve been missing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: As U.S. Tariffs Become Reality, Canadians Prepare for Economic Pain
description: An expert in the automotive industry says factories may shut down in days as costs skyrocket and President Trump disrupts decades of economic integration with steep tariffs.
content: The trucks that carry about $300 million worth of auto parts each day over the bridge from Windsor, Ontario, to Detroit are still rolling as usual. But in the aftermath of President Trump’s decision to impose 25 percent tariffs on most categories of Canadian exports, the mood in Windsor, like all of Canada, was transformed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: L.A. County Sues Southern California Edison Over Eaton Fire
description: The county says electrical equipment owned by the electric utility is to blame for the blaze that killed 17 people and destroyed 9,400 buildings.
content: Los Angeles County sued Southern California Edison and its parent company on Wednesday, blaming the utility’s equipment for causing the deadly Eaton fire in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Weight Loss Drug Will Be Offered for $499 a Month for Some Patients
description: Some commercially insured patients stand to save $150 per month on Wegovy, a popular obesity medication. Patients on Medicare and Medicaid are not eligible.
content: Novo Nordisk will cut the price of its blockbuster weight loss medication Wegovy to $499 per month for certain patients who pay using their own money instead of going through insurance, the drug maker said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Frustration Grows Inside the White House Over Pace of Deportations
description: President Trump’s promise to launch the largest deportation operation in U.S. history is colliding with the practical difficulties of detaining people and transporting them across the globe.
content: Just about every week since taking office, President Trump has called Thomas D. Homan, the enforcer of his immigration agenda, looking for an update on mass deportations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Pierre Joris, Translator of the ‘Impossible’ Paul Celan, Dies at 78
description: A notable poet in his own right, he was best known for rendering into English the words of a poet who reacted to the Holocaust by inventing a new version of German.
content: Pierre Joris, a poet and translator who tackled some of the 20th century’s most difficult verse, rendering into English the complex work of the German-Romanian poet Paul Celan, died on Feb. 27 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupam B. Jena
title: A New Way of Thinking About the N.I.H.
description: Can Dr. Jay Bhattacharya reform America’s primary medical research agency?
content: The National Institutes of Health is the United States’ primary medical research agency. It is renowned worldwide for funding and leading science that has transformed the understanding of disease and spurred lifesaving medical treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: L.A. Fire Chief Loses Her Bid for Reinstatement
description: The former chief, Kristin Crowley, said the mayor had falsely accused her of mishandling the Palisades fire, but her dismissal was upheld by the City Council.
content: The former Los Angeles fire chief lashed out publicly at Mayor Karen Bass on Tuesday, telling the City Council that the mayor had made “multiple false accusations” when removing her from the department’s top office for her handling of the devastating Palisades fire in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Al Green, Who Heckled Trump, Is No Stranger to Dramatic Political Gestures
description: The Texas Democrat, who was ejected from the House chamber for shouting at President Trump during his Tuesday address, also introduced the first articles of impeachment against him in 2017.
content: Representative Al Green, Democrat of Texas, who was removed from the House chamber for heckling President Trump during his speech on Tuesday to a joint session of Congress, has a history of dramatic political gestures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Guarded N.I.H. Nominee Faces Sharp Questions on Vaccines and Research Cuts
description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, a professor of medicine at Stanford University, gained prominence during the Covid pandemic when he argued against lockdowns.
content: Under hostile questioning from senators of both parties, Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, President Trump’s nominee to lead the National Institutes of Health, said on Wednesday that he was “convinced” vaccines did not cause autism even as he urged more research on the question, which scientists say has long been settled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Arab Plan for Gaza Leaves Thorny Issues Unanswered
description: As Israel remains deadlocked with Hamas over key issues, Gaza’s future after the war ends appears no closer to a resolution.
content: When President Trump said last month that he wanted to move all of Gaza’s roughly two million residents out of the strip to Egypt and Jordan and transform the territory into a beachfront “Riviera” for tourism, the pressure was on Arab leaders horrified by the idea to come up with their own grand plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Children Were Forced to Torture Sam Nordquist, Prosecutors Say
description: Seven people are now charged with first-degree murder in connection with the death of Mr. Nordquist, a transgender man whose killing has drawn national attention.
content: Prosecutors in western New York on Wednesday provided disturbing new details about the killing of a 24-year-old transgender man, Sam Nordquist, who they said was sexually assaulted and tortured for several weeks earlier this year in a motel room in Canandaigua, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Full Transcript of President Trump’s Speech to Congress
description: In a speech to Congress in his first weeks in office, the president laid out his vision to remake U.S. policy on the military, trade, immigration and foreign aid.
content: President Trump delivered his address to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday. The following is a transcript of his remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Beil
title: 150 Years of Change: How Old Photos, Recaptured, Reveal a Shifting Climate
description: In the heart of Utah’s Uinta Mountains, a team of scientists is re-creating historical pictures to study how much, and how quickly, ecosystems are changing.
content: For 30 miles we bounce along a dirt road in southwestern Wyoming, heading toward a jagged skyline. It’s early September and the aspens are starting to turn yellow. As we climb toward the mountains, the air grows colder. Soon the road will see snowfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: In an address to Congress last night, President Trump pitched his flurry of early actions, including deportations of migrants and the use of tariffs against major trading partners, as necessary to restore the strength of the U.S. His administration, he said, is “just getting started.” Recap the speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christian Ulloriaq Jeppesen, Maya Tekeli and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Trump Said the U.S. Will ‘Get’ Greenland. Greenlanders Aren’t Impressed.
description: Or enthused by Mr. Trump’s promise that “we will make you rich.”
content: President Trump had a special message on Tuesday night for the “incredible people of Greenland,” whose island he has repeatedly expressed interest in acquiring — through a purchase or by force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Hamilton’ Cancels Kennedy Center Run Over Trump’s Takeover
description: “We’re not going to be a part of it while it is the Trump Kennedy Center,” said the show’s creator, Lin-Manuel Miranda.
content: “Hamilton,” the musical theater juggernaut about the birth of American democracy, is canceling plans to perform next year at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, citing President Trump’s moves to impose his ideological and cultural values on the long-cherished venue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Carmakers Were Given a Monthlong Reprieve From Tariffs
description: Also, meet the man who wants to save the world from bad sound. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: President Trump announced today that cars would receive a one-month exemption from the sweeping 25 percent tariffs he imposed this week on imports from Mexico and Canada. The president said he made the decision after speaking with America’s three largest automakers, whom he pushed to move their production facilities to the U.S., according to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: Pakistan Needs Support Fighting Terrorism. A Happy Trump Could Help.
description: The president’s praise of the Pakistani government for its role in capturing a “top terrorist” signaled a possible strengthening of counterterrorism ties.
content: As President Trump delivered a speech to Congress on Tuesday night for the first time since re-entering the White House, one country made a surprising cameo: Pakistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Mark Landler
title: After Days of Coaching, Zelensky Seeks a Path to Trump’s Good Graces
description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain and President Emmanuel Macron of France have been prodding and counseling Volodymyr Zelensky on how to deal with President Trump.
content: The tutelage began last Friday, soon after President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine suffered through a humiliating dressing down at the White House, courtesy of President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Justice Dept. Indicts 12 Chinese in Hacking Plot Against U.S. Targets
description: The suspects were charged as part of what U.S. officials called a “hackers for hire” system whose primary customer was the Chinese government.
content: The Justice Department on Wednesday unsealed charges against a dozen Chinese citizens accused of being part of a sophisticated hacking ring that steals data from American businesses and people to sell to the Chinese government and others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Should I Tell My Son That His Best Friend Is Stealing From Him?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the importance of disclosure and trust among loved ones.
content: My son is a senior in college. His best friend and roommate for the last four years recently took something from him that was in a hiding place no one knew about except for my son and this friend. When my son confronted him, his friend denied it, only admitting that he took it after another guy confessed to participating in the theft. The friend never really addressed the issue other than to offer a brusque apology. My son was devastated and shocked that someone he considered “as close as a brother” would lie and steal from him. To add insult to injury, this individual comes from an affluent family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: D.C. Mayor Suggests Black Lives Matter Plaza Will Be Painted Over
description: The announcement came just a day after a Republican congressman introduced legislation threatening to withhold millions in federal funds from the city unless the street mural was removed.
content: The mayor of Washington, D.C., suggested on Tuesday night that the giant Black Lives Matter mural that was painted in the summer of 2020 on a street within view of the White House would be painted over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Small Contribution
description: Rebecca Goldstein gives us a witty jump scare.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher
title: ActBlue, the Democratic Fund-Raising Powerhouse, Faces Internal Chaos
description: At least seven senior officials have left the group, setting off deep concerns about its future as it confronts scrutiny from congressional Republicans.
content: ActBlue, the online fund-raising organization that powers Democratic candidates, has plunged into turmoil, with at least seven senior officials resigning late last month and a remaining lawyer suggesting he faced internal retaliation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump’s Defiant Victory Lap, and the Dept. of Education’s ‘Final Mission’
description: Plus, the sky-high cost of concert tickets.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Schneider
title: Most Contaminated U.S. Nuclear Site Is Set to Be the Largest Solar Farm
description: Plans to transform Hanford, which was integral to the nation’s nuclear arsenal after World War II, had just begun inching forward when President Trump started his second term.
content: In the weeks since President Trump has taken office, he has pushed to unleash oil and gas production and has signed executive orders halting the country’s transition to renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Byrd
title: A Jaw-Dropping Cooperative Game Lets Writers Run Wild
description: With influences from Contra, Metroid, Portal, Mario, Halo and more, Split Fiction follows two aspiring authors into the sci-fi and fantasy settings of their imaginations.
content: It seemed obvious after the first couple of hours of volleying frantic choreography instructions with my pal that Split Fiction will go down as one of the most beloved co-op games of this generation. There are so many moments in this split-screen adventure to savor with a companion, so many spectacles that make you pick your eyes up off the floor, that it’s hard to knock its shortcomings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: With ‘Fidelio,’ the Met Opera Does What It Does Best
description: The Met, a magnet for star singers, flexed its muscles to stack the cast of Beethoven’s only opera, with Lise Davidsen in the title role.
content: Opera houses tend to have their specialties. They might be havens for adventurous directors or unusual repertoire, for grand spectacles or Baroque chamber dramas. The Metropolitan Opera, at its finest, is a destination for voices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: King Charles III, a Quiet Diplomat, is Stepping Up
description: As he welcomed the leaders of Ukraine and Canada to his country estate this week, the king was sending a message to the world.
content: King Charles III flew by helicopter to the H.M.S. Prince of Wales in the English Channel on Tuesday, where he mingled with sailors and watched as fighter jets took off from the deck of the ship, a Royal Navy aircraft carrier. It might have been a welcome getaway from his suddenly complicated social life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: It’s Hard Not to Protest a Speech Like That
description: Democrats have spent weeks hand-wringing over how to respond to Trump’s machine-gunning of American institutions.
content: It may not have been the best possible day for President Trump to declare to Congress that “America’s momentum is back.” Just before he spoke, the stock market fell almost into correction territory, the result of deep concerns about his bizarre decision to enact tariffs on what used to be two of the country’s closest allies. Though he announced that “our confidence is back,” the actual confidence of consumers, as measured by the Conference Board, has fallen by the largest amount since August 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: 3 Helicopter Skiers Feared Dead in Alaska Avalanche, Officials Say
description: The group was traveling with guides from a commercial heli-skiing operation, which escorts backcountry skiers via helicopter to the tops of mountains that are otherwise inaccessible.
content: Three men were feared dead after they were swept away in an avalanche while on a helicopter skiing trip outside Anchorage on Tuesday, officials in Alaska said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How to Tell That the Chain Saw Is Coming for America
description: “Shock and awe” didn’t end well in Iraq and it won’t end well in the United States.
content: Every time I read that the strategy of the Trump team is “shock and awe” — a rapid, massive, multifront takeover of the U.S. government to shrink the bureaucracy and overturn established domestic and foreign policy priorities — I think back to the first time I heard that term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Tom Llamas Named Anchor of ‘NBC Nightly News’
description: Mr. Llamas, an anchor on the company’s streaming news service, will succeed Lester Holt, who last month announced his plans to step down.
content: Tom Llamas will take over as the anchor of NBC’s flagship news program, “NBC Nightly News,” the company said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Trans Workers Describe a ‘Betrayal’ by an Agency Meant to Protect Them
description: The nation’s primary regulator of workplace discrimination has moved to dismiss cases that may run afoul of President Trump’s executive order on gender.
content: When Asher Lucas’s co-workers started taunting him for being transgender, saying he was “born a girl and needed to be a girl,” he figured this type of bullying would not be tolerated at a well-known restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Our Daughter Expects Child Care Even When Her Toddler Is Sick. Help!
description: A reader who has already contracted colds and the flu from her 18-month-old grandchild is flustered by her daughter’s indifference to her health concerns.
content: My husband and I, in our 70s, provide child care for our 18-month-old granddaughter. She spends two days a week with us and three days in day care. She is frequently sick, and we have contracted R.S.V., colds and the flu from her. When I suggested to my daughter that she keep our grandchild at home on the worst days, she replied that my germophobic anxiety was causing her anxiety and that she would use the day care full time. (She also said I needed professional help.) The issue: My husband is devastated! He wants to care for our granddaughter whether she is sick or not. But if he gets sick, I will, too. I mask, but I am still exposed. So I am reluctant to make plans with friends, and I cancel others, for fear of infecting people. Meanwhile, my daughter accuses me of rejecting her “gift” of spending time with our granddaughter. Help!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: A Publisher Pulled a Romance Novel After Criticism From Early Readers
description: The novel, “Sparrow and Vine” by Sophie Lark, was due out in April from Bloom Books. Readers with advance copies criticized passages that they found racist — or that praised Elon Musk.
content: A forthcoming romance novel by the writer Sophie Lark was pulled by her publisher after drawing criticism from readers over dialogue that some found racist or that praised Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Democrats Target Adams at ‘Sanctuary City’ Hearing
description: Democratic lawmakers grilled Mayor Eric Adams of New York City over the circumstances behind the Justice Department’s move to dismiss his criminal case.
content: With New York City bearing the greatest burden of the nation’s migrant crisis, Mayor Eric Adams was expected to be a focus of the House oversight hearing on so-called sanctuary cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: With Rain on the Way, California’s Water Managers Are ‘Waiting With Bated Breath’
description: Back-to-back storms are expected over the next 10 days, potentially bringing a key measure of the state’s crucial water supply up to normal levels.
content: California is staring down a round of storms that will bring intermittent rain and snow across the state over the next 10 days, and, with the wet season more than two-thirds over, state water managers are watching the forecast closely, hoping these systems will deliver enough precipitation to offset a deficit in some places that have faced dangerously low levels of precipitation this winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Adidas Has Sold Its Last Yeezy Sneaker
description: The sportswear maker was eager to put the scandal with the rapper Ye behind it, but its cautious earnings forecast showed the breakup’s effects still lingered.
content: Adidas said Wednesday that it had sold its last pair of Yeezys, a wildly popular and profitable sneaker brand it developed with the rapper and designer Ye, as it tried to move past the publicity nightmare that followed after Ye’s antisemitic comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justices can find these speeches to Congress to be a trial.
description: Four sitting members of the court attended on Tuesday: Chief Justice Roberts and Justices Kagan, Kavanaugh and Barrett.
content: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. makes a point of going to the State of the Union address. But he does not enjoy it, once calling it “a political pep rally.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Former Nassau County Detective Who Moonlighted for Mafia Is Convicted
description: Hector Rosario had hoped to earn big from his work for the Bonanno crime family. He wound up with about $8,000 and an indictment.
content: The assignment carried a lot of risk and not much reward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Why Did New York’s Streets Seem Extra Salty This Winter?
description: The city didn’t actually spread more salt than usual. But it may have seemed that way, according to the Sanitation Department, because there was less snow and rain.
content: The last snowfall in New York City is fading from memory. It didn’t amount to much — less than half an inch — and didn’t stick around for long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Florida Attorney General Opens Criminal Investigation Into Tate Brothers
description: Andrew Tate and his brother Tristan Tate face human-trafficking charges in Romania and Britain. They arrived in Florida last week after a Romanian court lifted travel restrictions.
content: Florida’s attorney general on Tuesday opened a criminal investigation into Andrew Tate and his brother Tristan Tate, the British American online influencers who face human-trafficking charges in Romania and Britain, after they arrived in the state last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Boston’s Mayor Appears to Relish Pushing Back Against Republicans in House Hearing
description: Under contentious questioning over her city’s immigration policies, Mayor Michelle Wu challenged the “false narrative” that “immigrants cause all kinds of harm and danger.”
content: More than the other mayors who appeared before the House Oversight Committee on Wednesday, who seemed pained at times, Michelle Wu of Boston appeared to lean into the friction in the hearing over the cities’ immigration policies, seeming to relish the opportunity to push back against the assertions of Republican committee members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Thursday Briefing: How Trump’s Aid Halt May Affect Ukraine
description: Plus, the return of moviegoing in France.
content: European leaders are set to meet in Brussels today to discuss how to support Ukraine and strengthen their own military capabilities. President Trump’s decision yesterday to halt U.S. intelligence sharing with Ukraine, on the heels of his pause on military aid shipments, could reorder the battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Turing Award Goes to 2 Pioneers of Artificial Intelligence
description: Andrew Barto and Richard Sutton developed reinforcement learning, a technique vital to chatbots like ChatGPT.
content: In 1977, Andrew Barto, as a researcher at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, began exploring a new theory that neurons behaved like hedonists. The basic idea was that the human brain was driven by billions of nerve cells that were each trying to maximize pleasure and minimize pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Justice Dept. to Investigate U.C. System Over Allegations of Antisemitism
description: A type of inquiry typically used to look for racism within police departments will be used to examine whether the University of California system allowed harassment of Jewish students and staff.
content: The Trump administration said Wednesday it would use a law typically meant to investigate racist practices within police departments to examine whether the University of California system had engaged in a pattern or practice of antisemitic discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A ‘Greatest Showman’ Musical Is Coming to the Stage, in Britain
description: The show, developed by Disney with a Tony-winning creative team, will have an initial production in Bristol, England, in the spring of 2026.
content: “The Greatest Showman,” a hit 2017 film about the circus impresario P.T. Barnum, is being adapted for the stage by Disney Theatrical Group and will have an initial production in early 2026 in Bristol, England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Far-Right Israeli Minister Visits Washington After Years of Being Shunned
description: Bezalel Smotrich, the Israeli finance minister, had drawn rebukes from the Biden administration for his opposition to a cease-fire in Gaza and his support for Jewish settlers in the West Bank.
content: Under the Biden administration, Israel’s far-right finance minister was the rare Israeli official whom the United States rebuked by name for his views, like his opposition to a cease-fire in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Federal Judge Extends Block on N.I.H. Cuts to Research Funding
description: The order is a temporary reprieve for hospitals and universities who have argued that the changes sought by the National Institutes of Health would devastate their budgets.
content: A federal judge said on Wednesday that the National Institutes of Health must continue to hold off on planned cuts to federal funding underpinning a variety of medical and scientific research while the court case plays out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: To Stop Tariffs, Trump Demands Opioid Data That Doesn’t Yet Exist
description: A top administration official said that, without new declines in overdose deaths, tariffs on Canada and Mexico were appropriate. But the kind of real-time data he demanded doesn’t exist.
content: One month ago, President Trump agreed to delay tariffs on Canada and Mexico after the two countries agreed to help stem the flow of fentanyl into the United States. On Tuesday, the Trump administration imposed the tariffs anyway, saying that the countries had failed to do enough — and claiming that tariffs would be lifted only when drug deaths fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter, Aurelien Breeden and Ségolène Le Stradic
title: In Mass Child Sex Abuse Case in France, Early Warnings Went Unheeded
description: Joël Le Scouarnec is charged with raping or sexually assaulting 299 people, mostly his young patients. His family’s testimony suggested a culture of silence around sexual abuse by him and others.
content: The alarms about Joël Le Scouarnec’s sexual desire for children had been ringing for years, well before he was charged with raping or sexually assaulting 299 people, most of them children under his care when he was a surgeon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
title: Attorney General’s Brother Seeks to Lead D.C. Bar Association
description: Bradley Bondi, brother of Pam Bondi, is running for president of Washington’s bar association, which may consider complaints against political appointees in the Justice Department.
content: Bradley J. Bondi, brother of Attorney General Pam Bondi, has announced his candidacy to lead the bar association in Washington at a time when the group might be asked to consider accusations that political appointees at the Justice Department violated professional or ethical norms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Johnson
title: 15 Easy Baking Recipes for When You Really, Really Need a Treat
description: Be ready when the craving strikes.
content: Sometimes baking is about the journey: It’s fun to whisk warm sugar into egg whites for an Italian meringue, then fold it carefully into a batter. And sometimes, it’s about the destination. You want a baked good — as soon as possible. That’s when the recipes below come in handy. Rest assured that they’re just as satisfying as those bigger baking projects, but, this time, you can linger over the eating, and not the whisking or kneading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,356
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, March 6, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The State of Himself
description: Trump hasn’t altered his behavior to be president. He altered the presidency to match his personality.
content: Interviewing Donald Trump over the decades, I would sometimes do a lightning round of questions at the end. It was always his favorite part. He relished giving short bursts of opinion on a range of political and cultural topics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Paulina Villegas
title: ‘We Have Given Him Everything’: Trump’s Tariffs Stun Mexico
description: President Claudia Sheinbaum’s government made major concessions — and delivered results — to avert President Trump’s 25 percent tariffs. He imposed them anyway.
content: Up to the last minute, Isaac Presburger, like a lot of other Mexican businessmen, still could not believe that President Trump would deliver on his promise to hit Mexico with tariffs. Little did it matter that Mr. Trump had announced that very day that he would go ahead with the planned taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Sales Slump in Europe as Anger Toward Elon Musk Grows
description: February numbers show the U.S. electric-car maker is struggling to attract buyers in the region. Mr. Musk’s politics aren’t helping.
content: Tesla’s sales in Germany plunged in February, part of a wider slump across Europe that has undercut the company’s share price and highlighted anger at the political activities of Elon Musk, the company’s chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A Weighty and Whimsical Century of The New Yorker’s Archives
description: An exhibition at the New York Public Library celebrates the magazine’s literary stars and unsung office heroes.
content: The archives of The New Yorker, housed at the New York Public Library, consist of more than 2,500 boxes of manuscripts, letters, page proofs, cartoons, art, photographs and memos. They are studded with the celebrated names — E.B. White, J.D. Salinger, John Updike, Rachel Carson — that filled this most mythologized of magazines, and helped transform American literary life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘Bed Party’
description: What do you think of a new style of celebration that involves parents tricking out their child’s bed after a college acceptance?
content: Imagine you just got into the college of your dreams: How would you celebrate?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Democrats Appear in Pink to Protest
description: But is this really a “Barbie” moment?
content: Forget white suffragist pantsuits, the political uniform of the female Trump opposition during the president’s first term. On Tuesday night during President Trump’s address to a joint session of Congress, about three dozen members of the Democratic Women’s Caucus wore bright hues of pink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Jillian Weinberger
title: Elon Musk and the Useless Spending-Cut Theater of DOGE
description: The columnist David French speaks with a fellow fiscal conservative about what the Department of Government Efficiency should actually be doing.
content: As a fiscal conservative, the columnist David French held some hope for Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency before President Trump took office. Those hopes were quickly dashed. In this conversation with the Manhattan Institute’s Jessica Riedl, French reckons with what Musk and his department have wrought on the government and argues that DOGE will do little to ameliorate the proposed tax cuts in the budget resolution recently passed by the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Trump Is Hiding Something on Ukraine
description: When you don’t call things by their real name, there is usually a reason.
content: Whenever President Trump talks about Ukraine there is always something off, something missing, that makes you wonder what he is really up to — and his brief remarks on Ukraine to a joint session of Congress Tuesday night were no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil Prices Slide on Jitters Over Trump’s Tariffs and OPEC Increases
description: The international benchmark fell to its lowest point since 2021 after a decision by Saudi Arabia and other producers to pump more crude surprised the markets.
content: Oil prices swooned on Wednesday as economic uncertainty rippled through global markets, a reaction to President Trump’s tariffs on Canada, China and Mexico and a decision by members of the OPEC Plus oil cartel to begin increasing crude production in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘It Was 90-Plus Minutes of Bad Moments’: 9 Opinion Writers on Trump’s Address to Congress
description: What Times Opinion columnists and writers thought of the president’s speech to Congress.
content: President Trump addressed a joint session of Congress Tuesday night, casting himself as the leader of a revolution that had already restored free speech, saved American automakers from destruction and ushered in “the greatest and most successful era in the history of our country.” It was “a time for big dreams and bold action,” he told Congress. Soon, he said, he’d balance the budget, end the war in Ukraine and bring back “true democracy.” Here’s what our writers thought of his speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Democratic Response to Trump Shows a Party Divided on How to Resist Him
description: Party leaders opted for a soberly delivered, centrist counter to the president’s speech, but the dominant image of Democratic pushback was a liberal congressman waving his cane in protest.
content: To counter President Trump’s first major address of his second term, Democrats in Congress selected a middle-aged woman senator with a background in national security to deliver a simple, centrist message, devoid of partisan animus, aimed at voters across the political spectrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Juan Hamilton, Georgia O’Keeffe’s Companion and Contested Heir, Dies at 79
description: As a young potter, he turned up on the doorstep of an octogenarian master of modern painting. They grew so close it became a scandal.
content: Juan Hamilton, an aspiring artist who enriched the last years of the painter Georgia O’Keeffe as her much younger caretaker, confidant and protégé, but who became the object of sensational accusations as virtually the sole beneficiary of her will, died on Feb. 20 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlene Bauer
title: This Writer Isn’t Afraid to Get Weird
description: In a new essay collection, A. Kendra Greene translates her experiences of our bizarre and marvelous world.
content: “It is a thing the essay loves: to tend, carefully, painstakingly, to the fact of the world,” A. Kendra Greene writes in “No Less Strange or Wonderful,” her new book of essays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: South Africa Prepares Trade Deal Meant to Ease Tensions With Trump
description: Lawmakers were warned that the United States is planning more punitive actions against the country. Officials hope a new trade deal will help repair the icy relations.
content: South Africa is preparing a new trade offer to present to President Trump, hoping to appeal to his transactional approach to foreign policy and ease boiling tensions with Washington, a spokesman for South Africa’s president said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: Joan Didion Knew the Stories We’d Tell About the Manson Murders
description: Didion’s influential account of the era, “The White Album,” captures the ripples of terror provoked by the 1969 murders.
content: Few true crime villains dominate American imaginations as fiercely as Charles Manson and his “family” of lost youths. The story has everything: a wild-eyed mastermind who was also a failed rocker; a coterie of emaciated, beautiful women; the death of a gorgeous pregnant actress and her friends; strange links to the Beatles; a feeling that this murder was either random, or an indication that hell had broken loose on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Odell
title: Fashion Has Given Up on Being Woke, and That’s OK
description: Fashion spent a decade trying to be socially conscious but now is going all in on opulence and catering to the powerful.
content: Fashion Weeks in New York, Milan and Paris have been unapologetically decadent this year. Beige is out, red is in. Real fur is back. Eighties maximalism is elbowing aside ’90s minimalism. Sean Monahan, a trend forecaster, calls it the “boom boom” aesthetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing
title: Trump to Pause Auto Tariffs for One Month as Other Levies Continue
description: The president said he would pause a 25 percent tariff on cars coming from Canada and Mexico under a trade pact for one month, while other levies stay in place.
content: President Trump said on Wednesday that he would pause tariffs on cars coming into the United States from Canada and Mexico for one month, after a 25 percent tariff that he placed on America’s closest trading partners a day earlier roiled stock markets and prompted stiff resistance from industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Trump’s Bid to Freeze Foreign Aid
description: The move came after Chief Justice Roberts temporarily paused a trial judge’s order requiring the administration to release more than $1.5 billion.
content: The Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected President Trump’s emergency request to freeze nearly $2 billion in foreign aid in a closely divided decision indicating that the justices will subject his efforts to reshape the government to close scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Tariffs Add a New Shock to Food Supply Chains
description: Companies made their supply chains stronger and more flexible because of the Covid pandemic. But they weren’t banking on tariffs.
content: Victoria Gutierrez has been thinking about avocados a lot lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: Trump Says Japan and South Korea Want to Invest in $44 Billion Gas Project
description: Investors have balked at the project, stalling its progress. But under the threat of tariffs, Japan and South Korea have started exploring ways to invest in Alaska L.N.G.
content: President Trump said on Tuesday that Japan and South Korea want to work with the United States on a $44 billion plan to produce and export natural gas from Alaska, reviving interest in one of the world’s biggest energy projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Supreme Court’s Ruling a Victory for Foreign Aid Groups, but How Big Is Unclear
description: The groups that sued insist the court’s ruling ought to force the Trump administration to restore all funding delivered via U.S.A.I.D. But the administration says it has the power to decimate the agency.
content: The Supreme Court’s Wednesday ruling that the Trump administration must heed a lower court’s order to release frozen foreign aid was a welcome but confusing development for humanitarian and development organizations around the world, as they waited to see if thousands of canceled contracts would be restarted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Chefs Making PB&J for Adults
description: Plus: a Nordic guesthouse, graphic prints on the runways and more from T’s cultural compendium.
content: In a 1901 article in the Boston Cooking School Magazine of Culinary Science & Domestic Economics, the food writer Julia Davis Chandler introduced one of America’s most iconic culinary couples: peanut butter and jelly. In the time since, PB&J has dominated school lunchboxes and shown up in various packaged treats, from Uncrustables to M&M’s. Now pastry chefs like New York’s Miro Uskokovic, 41, are embracing and updating the pairing. At Hani’s, the East Village bakery that he co-owns with his wife, Shilpa, PB&J cake is a perpetual best seller. “With desserts, you should never go too intellectual,” says Uskokovic, who sandwiches wild blueberry compote, peanut butter buttercream and peanut-sesame crunch between layers of yellow sponge. “I haven’t met many people who don’t like PB&J.” At Brio, an Italian restaurant in Amsterdam, the chef Maddy Caldwell, 24, serves a frozen version of the combo, topping her ice cream sundae with peanut sauce and quince jelly, while in Asheville, N.C., Owl Bakery’s Lola Borovyk, 32, simmers local muscadine grapes into jam and then combines them with peanut frangipane and streusel in a twice-baked croissant. “It’s lowbrow meets highbrow,” she says. At Hellbender, a Mexican American restaurant in Ridgewood, Queens, the executive chef Yara Herrera, 33, took inspiration from another childhood favorite: Jell-O. Her parfait features alternating stripes of silky peanut butter and concord grape gelatin with a topping of whipped cream and candied peanuts. Originally conceived of as a special, the dessert was so popular that it’s become a menu mainstay. Says Herrera, “I don’t think PB&J is ever going out of style.” — Tanya Bush
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt, Marc Santora and Julian E. Barnes
title: Trump’s Decision to Halt Aid to Ukraine Could Reorder the Battlefield
description: Officials have suggested that the pause in weapons shipments and intelligence sharing could be relatively short-lived if Ukraine’s president bends to White House demands.
content: On the battlefields of Ukraine and western Russia, a stalemated war has ground on, with Ukrainian troops defending against Russian progress that can be measured sometimes in mere yards. The cost has been heavy casualties on both sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A Rally in Congress
description: We cover President Trump’s address to Congress.
content: Last night, President Trump gave what sounded like a campaign speech. He mocked Democrats, decried “wokeness,” bragged about his accomplishments and repeated falsehoods. Except this speech wasn’t delivered at a rally. It was in Congress, and the audience included Democrats. The mood was sour, and the parties jeered at each other. The evening showcased the chasm in our polarized politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Aging Women’s Brain Mysteries Are Tested in Trio of Studies
description: Researchers identified a gene that seems to help slow brain aging in women, and studied links between hormone therapy, menopause and Alzheimer’s.
content: Women’s brains are superior to men’s in at least in one respect — they age more slowly. And now, a group of researchers reports that they have found a gene in mice that rejuvenates female brains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Gallow
title: An Island Cabin Touched by Lots of Hands
description: How artisans in a corner of the Pacific Northwest turned a rocky retreat into a permanent residence.
content: On the San Juan Islands off northwest Washington State, land meets sea along rocky outcrops, and views stretch to Canada. Weather and water command the field, and the pace of life bends to meet them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Steeling My Daughters Against a New Kind of Misogyny
description: What keeps me up at night about the feminist backlash we’re living through.
content: Since President Trump started announcing his cabinet picks, I have been trying to write a Very Serious Essay about the Current State of Feminism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: More Than 36 Million Watched Trump’s Address to Congress on Live TV
description: The annual presidential speech is one of the last remaining mass-audience media moments available to a national politician.
content: About 36.6 million Americans watched President Trump live on television on Tuesday night, tuning in for his 100-minute speech to a joint session of Congress — the longest of its kind in the modern era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Most Voters Want Eric Adams to Resign as Approval Rating Hits Record Low
description: More than half of New York City voters surveyed in a Quinnipiac University poll said that Mayor Eric Adams should resign.
content: Just 20 percent of New York City voters approved of Mayor Eric Adams’s job performance in a poll released Wednesday, and more than half said he should resign, demonstrating that he faces a daunting path to re-election this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Rohman
title: Concert Ticket Prices Are Soaring, and Busting Gen Z’s Budgets
description: How can 20-somethings afford the high cost of seeing their favorite artists’ live shows? Some save; some go into debt.
content: Ignacio Vasquez spent the last year saving money for tickets to Beyoncé’s Cowboy Carter tour, which will kick off next month. Mr. Vasquez, 20, a full-time student from Modesto, Calif., was on the lookout for tickets to one of the tour’s five shows at SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles for him and his sister.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lace-Up Shoes That Feel Timeless
description: Inspired by classic designs, pared-down sneakers are spring’s most versatile accessories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: With Game Show Flair, Trump Recognizes Guests at Capitol Address
description: A child with cancer, the mother of a murder victim and a newly admitted student to an American military academy were given the spotlight during the president’s speech.
content: During his lengthy address to Congress on Tuesday night, President Trump blended solemn tributes with a flair for showmanship, as he acknowledged guests in the House chamber and showered them with praise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Vjosa Isai
title: Canadians and Wayne Gretzky: Anatomy of a Relationship on Thin Ice
description: In tense political times, can “The Great One” be both a Trump supporter and a beloved hero in Canada? Some want him to pick a side. (Preferably the one to the north.)
content: Where have you gone, Wayne Gretzky? A nation turns its lonely eyes to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Josh Holder
title: How Soon Could Ukraine’s Forces ‘Start to Buckle’ Without U.S. Weapons?
description: It could be as little as four months, say analysts, as Europe scrambles to plug the hole in support left by President Trump’s suspension of military aid.
content: Without billions of dollars in American-made weapons, it may be only a matter of time before Ukraine’s forces falter against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Promised Retribution. Turns Out He Had a Very Big Target in Mind.
description: It is hard to describe the president’s first month and a half in office as something other than a retribution campaign against the American people.
content: Donald Trump rambled, ranted and raved his way through the 2024 presidential campaign, but he was clear on one point. When he was elected, he would get revenge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Serendipity Still Exists’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Another rider joins the Lyft pool. Now I might be late for my date. “Mustafa?” the new rider asks. “Yes. Melissa?” Wait a minute, I think. I’m on my way to meet a Melissa. “Melissa?” I say. “Yes?” she replies. “It’s Erik.” She doesn’t put two and two together. Awkward silence ensues. “Oh, you’re actually going to the same place,” says Mustafa. “Really? Why are you going there?” Melissa asks. “Uh, I think I’m going on a date with you,” I say. Mustafa laughs. We join in. I feel briefly hopeful that, despite apps and algorithms, serendipity still exists. — Erik Moyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: OpenAI’s C.E.O. Returns to Political Fund-Raising
description: Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, is set to host a fund-raiser for Senator Mark Warner, Democrat of Virginia.
content: Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, has spent the last few months cozying up to the Trump administration, attending his inauguration and launching a data-center project that President Trump mentioned in Tuesday’s address to Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Histories of Native America and the Port of Los Angeles Win Bancroft Prize
description: The award, one of the most prestigious among scholars of American history, honors “scope, significance, depth of research and richness of interpretation.”
content: A sweeping history of Native Americans and a study of the creation of the port of Los Angeles in the 19th century have won this year’s Bancroft Prize, one of the most distinguished honors for scholars of American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
title: Gaming Out Trump’s Next Tariff Moves
description: In his address to Congress, the president made clear that his new trade levies were here to stay, acknowledging it might create “a little disturbance.” Analysts forecast what that might look like.
content: For months, the debate gripping board rooms, Wall Street and world capitals was whether to take President Trump at his word on tariffs. For a while, the markets rallied as if he were just bluffing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Chicago’s Mayor Pushes Back as Republicans Attack Immigration Policies
description: Mayor Brandon Johnson argued that Chicago’s policies made the city safer and allowed residents to help the police solve crimes without fear of deportation.
content: Mayor Brandon Johnson of Chicago defended his record and his city’s policy of not proactively helping immigration officials during hours of hostile questioning from congressional Republicans on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Judge Denies Musk’s Request to Block OpenAI’s For-Profit Plan
description: The court said that Elon Musk could proceed with other parts of a lawsuit he brought against OpenAI last year.
content: In November, Elon Musk asked a federal court to block OpenAI’s plan to transform itself from a nonprofit into a purely for-profit company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Takeaways From a Contentious Hearing on Big-City Immigration Policies
description: Republicans accused the mayors of New York, Chicago, Denver and Boston of providing sanctuary to criminals, while Democrats pointed to falling crime rates and defended helping the needy.
content: House Republicans cast the mayors of four major American cities as willful impediments to President Trump’s mass deportation agenda during a tense congressional hearing on Wednesday. But in doing so, Republicans also gave the leaders a national platform to passionately defend their cities’ policies and immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $850,000 Homes in Florida, Rhode Island and New Mexico
description: A condo in Miami, a 1920s cottage in Newport and an adobe house in Taos.
content: This two-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bathroom unit is in a central Miami neighborhood within walking distance of the Miami Design District and the Wynwood Walls, an outdoor street-art installation. A shopping center with a Target is a few blocks away, as is a Trader Joe’s. Albert Pallot Park, which has a playground and walking trails that run along the edge of Biscayne Bay, is 15 minutes away on foot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold
title: Department of Government Efficiency Deletes a Claim and Resurrects an Error
description: DOGE removed any mention of a long-dead contract from its website, where the government-cutting team has repeatedly posted erroneous “receipts” inflating its success.
content: The Department of Government Efficiency has deleted one of its more bizarre claims: that it had saved taxpayers $53.7 million by “canceling” a federal contract that had actually ended in 2005.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Trump Is Changing America From the Top. These Groups Did It From the Bottom.
description: A new book by the historian Linda Gordon considers seven social movements that transformed the country — not all of them for the better.
content: This is what political upheaval looks like when delivered from on high: The president of the United States directs the world’s richest man to descend on federal agencies and treat them like a private company, slashing funding and purging workers, with nary a peep from the Republican majority in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Fired CDC Scientists Are Reinstated for Now
description: The fellows had been let go as part of the push to cut federal probationary employees that caused thousands of scientists from the C.D.C. and other agencies to lose their jobs.
content: Barely two weeks after they were fired, dozens of young scientists at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention were reinstated on Tuesday — at least temporarily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Top Democrats Accuse Trump and Musk of Imperiling National Security
description: The senior Democrats on the Senate and House national security panels, who typically moderate their public statements given their positions, issued a scathing statement before the president’s speech.
content: Top congressional Democrats on military, intelligence and foreign policy matters on Tuesday accused President Trump and Elon Musk of gravely undermining national security by aligning with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and dismantling the federal security work force at a perilous time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: This Trump Speech Was the Ultimate Loyalty Test
description: Something has ruptured in American politics.
content: The economy has started blinking red. President Trump’s tariffs have been roiling markets. Consumer sentiment was already down. G.D.P. forecasts are predicting slower growth. And on Tuesday night Trump declared to Congress and the nation that things had never been better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Cheung
title: Joy, and Selfies, at the Oscars
description: Timothée Chalamet, Demi Moore, Cynthia Erivo, Ariana Grande and other stars dropped their guard on Hollywood’s biggest night.
content: The Academy Awards can be a fraught affair. When many of the world’s biggest stars gather to be validated for their artistry, the tension of parsing the winners from non-winners (not losers!) threatens to stultify the whole thing. But at Sunday night’s Oscars ceremony — where “Anora” (and Sean Baker) won big, Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande belted big-hearted songs, and Adrien Brody kissed and was kissed — our photographer caught the stars in unguarded moments of joyful support and celebration throughout the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: Al Green Removed From House Chamber for Heckling Trump During Address
description: Republicans had the Texas Democrat, who introduced the first articles of impeachment against Trump in 2017, ejected after he shouted at the president and refused to sit down.
content: President Trump got barely two minutes into his speech to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday night before Representative Al Green, Democrat of Texas, stood to protest, disrupting the proceedings in a display that ultimately got him thrown out of the House chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Landon Nordeman
title: Paris Gets Its Own Met Gala
description: Doechii, Michelle Yeoh, Dev Patel and more stars mingled with fashion’s celebrities at the first fashion-fabulous Grand Dîner du Louvre.
content: There was theater at Dior on Day 1 of Paris Fashion Week. Powerful glamour at Alaïa. But for real-life dressing drama, nothing compared to the fashion show that took place in front of the luminous glass pyramid of the Louvre on the opening evening of the collections, as guests arrived for the museum’s gala Grand Dîner, which many not-so-jokingly referred to as the museum’s mini-Met Gala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sylvester Turner, Sworn In as U.S. Representative in January, Dies at 70
description: A former mayor of Houston, he was in attendance at the president’s speech on Tuesday night and was later taken to a hospital.
content: Sylvester Turner, a former mayor of Houston who was sworn in as a U.S. representative in January, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 70 and had been in attendance at President Trump’s speech on Capitol Hill on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: Judge Blocks Trump Orders to Stop Funds for Trans Youth Health Providers
description: The ruling affects hospitals nationwide, putting on hold the administration’s plan to withhold research grants from those that offer gender transition treatments to young people.
content: Federal funding for hospitals across the country that provide gender-transition treatments for people under the age of 19 will remain in place under a federal judge’s ruling in Baltimore on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: In ‘Deli Boys,’ Two Actors Find Dream Roles Playing No One’s Hero
description: Saagar Shaikh and Asif Ali will do “unspeakable things” in a Hulu comedy that centers on South Asians, drugs, violence — and the minimart.
content: It had happened to Saagar Shaikh many times: He would audition for a part, get a callback, then never hear from anyone again. Later, when he would watch the show, movie or commercial he had auditioned for, the same guy always seemed to fill the role he had wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Women With Postpartum Depression Experienced Brain Changes During Pregnancy, Study Finds
description: The research constitutes some of the first evidence that the condition is associated with modifications in the brain before childbirth.
content: Postpartum depression affects about one in every seven women who give birth, but little is known about what happens in the brains of pregnant women who experience it. A new study begins to shed some light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman, Mooj Zadie, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Rachel Quester, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Partisan Taunts and Defiant Protests: Trump’s First Speech to Congress
description: President Trump’s highly partisan victory lap, and the reactions to it in the room.
content: In his first address to Congress on Tuesday night, President Trump took a highly partisan victory lap as Democratic lawmakers openly protested against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Warning That Trump Will ‘Make You Pay,’ Slotkin Gives Democratic Response
description: The Michigan Democrat, a first-term senator, opted for a simple and brief response to President Trump’s speech, arguing that his agenda would be costly for Americans and leave them less safe.
content: Senator Elissa Slotkin, a first-term Democrat from Michigan, delivered a simple message as her party’s official response to President Trump’s combative and lengthy address to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday night: Mr. Trump, she said, was “going to make you pay in every part of your life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Signals It Will End Challenge to Idaho Abortion Ban
description: The Trump administration is poised to roll back a Biden-era legal effort to blunt the effects of the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
content: The Justice Department plans to drop a Biden-era challenge to Idaho’s law banning abortion in nearly all circumstances, a move that could end access to most abortions for women in the state whose pregnancy poses serious health risks, according to a court filing on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Economic Plan Is Light on Detail as Trade War Intensifies
description: The country’s top leaders set an optimistic growth target but gave few hints of how to achieve it as their export-led strategy is challenged by rising tariffs on Chinese goods.
content: For months, China has promised to help its people spend more to turn the economy around, while taking few concrete measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Chang and Gritchelle Fallesgon
title: Test Your Body Awareness
description: This sixth sense helps you stay balanced and injury free, especially as you age.
content: To hit a tennis ball or dance the merengue you need sharp eyes and a good ear. But there’s also another rarely discussed sense at work: proprioception, or body awareness. While it’s not one of the classic five senses, body awareness is crucial to moving and aging with grace. And it can be trained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Hackers Stole $635,000 in Taylor Swift Ticket Scheme, Queens D.A. Says
description: Two people stand accused of taking hundreds of tickets from StubHub to redirect them to others who resold them, prosecutors said.
content: Two people accused of stealing and reselling more than 900 tickets to the Taylor Swift Eras Tour and other marquee events are facing criminal charges for their role in the scheme, New York prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Natalie Proulx
title: Do You Have a ‘Third Place’?
description: Besides home and school, where do you go to gather with others on a regular basis?
content: Besides home and school, where do you go to gather with others on a regular basis?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: In ‘The Electric State,’ Jolting a Robot to Life
description: How the makers of a new Netflix science fiction movie enhanced the look of the cute, round-headed bot at its center.
content: Kid Cosmo’s head is enormous, as robot heads go. The primary nonhuman hero of the film “The Electric State” (on Netflix March 14), Cosmo has a bright yellow globe of a head the size and shape of an exercise ball, propped atop an incongruously spindly frame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Gene Hackman’s 2 Surviving Dogs Are Healthy and Safe, Boarder Says
description: A third dog that was found dead last week with the couple was an Australian Kelpie mix named Zinna, the boarder said.
content: Even those who knew very little about the lives of the retired actor Gene Hackman and his wife, Betsy Arakawa, still knew that they loved their dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Luke Broadwater
title: A Combative Trump Says ‘America Is Back’ and Taunts His Political Rivals
description: President Trump boasted about his first weeks in office and doubled down on his agenda. Al Green, a Democratic lawmaker from Texas, repeatedly yelled “you don’t have a mandate” and was escorted out.
content: President Trump vowed not to lift tariffs on America’s biggest trading partners in his first address to Congress on Tuesday, but appeared ready to reduce tensions with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine just days after an Oval Office blowup in which he threatened to abandon a key ally fighting an invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Zelensky Tries To Make Peace On Every Front
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 5, 2025.
content: “It was a kind of Pearl Harbor, a political Pearl Harbor, for us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bobby Finger
title: He Spent the Pandemic in a Coma. Can He Rebuild His Life?

content: Jazz has experienced a meaningful resurgence in popularity over the past 15 years or so, especially among younger listeners. What’s driving that? You could make the case that there is a particular hunger, now that so much of life is lived in the digital cloud, for the messy and untamed energy of jazz, and for its way of putting a live process on display. And if that’s the case, then it makes a lot of sense that Chicago jazz has been at the forefront of this recent surge. Chicago has always represented a particularly rootsy, physical and — yes — windy ideal in jazz. So perhaps it’s an especially heady antidote to that sense of digital disappearance.

content: The British designer Harry Pontefract’s clothing often starts with a very specific obsession.
